description: The Ziggurat of Ur (Sumerian: E-temen-nigur, 'House whose foundation creates terror/awe') is the best-preserved ziggurat in ancient Mesopotamia and one of the most significant monuments from humanity's earliest urban civilizations. Built around 2100 BCE by King Ur-Nammu, founder of the Third Dynasty of Ur, this massive stepped temple tower was dedicated to Nanna (Akkadian: Sin), the moon god and patron deity of the city. Originally rising approximately 30 meters (100 feet) above the flat Mesopotamian plain, the three-tiered structure was crowned by a temple where priests performed sacred rituals and the king communed with the divine. The ziggurat served as the religious heart of Ur, one of the ancient world's greatest cities and the biblical 'Ur of the Chaldees' - the traditional birthplace of the patriarch Abraham. Constructed of mud brick with a baked brick facade, it featured three monumental staircases converging at the first terrace level. Excavated by Sir Leonard Woolley in the 1920s-30s, the ziggurat revealed the sophistication of Sumerian engineering and religious practice. Partially restored by Saddam Hussein in the 1980s, it survived the Gulf Wars and remains a powerful symbol of Mesopotamian civilization - the culture that gave humanity writing, the wheel, and the earliest legal codes.
